facts.text: On June 13, 1963, Head Constable Baboo Khan on patrol duty came to the Chakki of Abdul Razaaq and saw a heap of Shakkar with labourers mixing Shelkhari in it with spades.

Head Constable informed Station Officer (not present), then Sanitary Inspector, who with Food Inspector went to Chakki and found labourers mixing Shelkhari with Shakkar. Stock of Shakkar belonged to appellant.
Food Inspector purchased 1-1/2 seers of Shakkar from appellant as sample after paying price, divided into three parts, gave one to appellant, retained two, sent one to Public Analyst.

Public Analyst report dated July 11, 1963: Shakkar contained 2.4% moisture, 72.7% total sugar, 64.7% sucrose, 17% extraneous matter insoluble in water. Extraneous matter exceeded by 15% (vs max 2%), total ash by 10.1% (vs 6%), ash insoluble in HCl by 13.3% (vs 0.5%).
Magistrate convicted appellant under section 16 r/w section 7 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, sentenced to 1 year RI and fine Rs.1000, default 6 months RI.

Sessions Judge acquitted appellant: prosecution failed to prove Shakkar stored for sale (mixing for converting to Rab); no standard prescribed for Shakkar (neither gur nor jaggery); sale to Food Inspector under duress, not a sale.

Allahabad High Court on April 12, 1968 restored Magistrate's conviction: Shakkar is jaggery with prescribed standards; adulterated; sample purchase by Food Inspector is sale u/s 2(xiii); power to sample even if stored for manufacture into Rab, not sale.

Para A.07.05 Appendix B Rules: Gur or jaggery is product from sugarcane/palm juice, standards: total sugars >=90%, sucrose >=70%, extraneous <=2%, ash <=6%, HCl insoluble <=0.5%, moisture <=10% for solid.
Shakkar is product obtained by boiling/processing sugarcane juice.

legal_issues.text: Whether Shakkar is jaggery for which standards are prescribed under the Rules, and if so, whether the sample was adulterated.
Whether the Shakkar was stored for sale or for manufacturing Rab, and whether sale to Food Inspector triggers liability under sections 7 and 16 even if not stored for sale.

petitioner_arguments.text: Shakkar is not jaggery, and no standard of quality prescribed for Shakkar under the Rules; hence not adulterated.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Appendix B of Rules under Prevention of Food Adulteration Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Shakkar kept for manufacturing Rab, not for sale; hence no offence under section 16 r/w section 7.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 7 and 16 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Appendix B describes but does not define jaggery to encompass all varieties of sugarcane products.

respondent_arguments.text: Shakkar is same as jaggery; standards prescribed apply; sample adulterated per Analyst report.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Appendix B of Rules; Prevention of Food Adulteration Act

respondent_arguments.text: Sample purchased by Food Inspector amounts to sale u/s 2(xiii); Food Inspector has power to sample even if stored for manufacture into Rab, not sale.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(xiii), 7, 16 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act

court_reasoning.text: Shakkar is jaggery as per Para A.07.05 Appendix B (product from sugarcane juice boiling/processing); definition encompasses it; dictionary confirms Shakkar as jaggery. Sample failed standards, hence adulterated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shakkar is jaggery; High Court finding correct.

court_reasoning.text: Even if Shakkar stored for manufacturing Rab not sale, sale to Food Inspector triggers s.16 liability as it is a sale u/s 2(xiii); no need to prove stored for sale if sold.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court finding that stored for sale correct, but even if not, conviction stands.

court_reasoning.text: Appendix B defines jaggery as any product from sugarcane juice process; comprehends Shakkar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejected contention that it only describes, not defines.

holdings.text: Shakkar is jaggery subject to prescribed standards; sample adulterated.
Sale to Food Inspector constitutes sale u/s 16 even if article not stored for sale or seller not dealer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Charukattil Gapalan
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale to Food Inspector is sale u/s 16; liability if adulterated, regardless of whether stored for sale or seller is dealer.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits storing/selling adulterated food; punishes manufacture/store/sale of adulterated food; defines 'sale' to include to Food Inspector.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upheld Allahabad High Court judgment restoring Magistrate's conviction and sentence of 1 year RI and Rs.1000 fine (default 6 months RI) under s.16 r/w s.7 of PFA Act.

key_quotes.text: "Shakkar is jaggery and the finding of the High Court, on the basis of the report of the Analyst, that the Shakkar has not conformed to the standard of quality prescribed for jaggery and, therefore, the food was adulterated, was correct."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms Shakkar as jaggery and adulteration.

key_quotes.text: "If Shakkar is an article of food, it does not matter whether the appellant kept it for sale, or for manufacturing Rab out of it, provided the appellant has sold it. And a sale to the Food Inspector is a sale for the purpose of section 16 of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on liability despite intent not for sale.
